awd_titl_txt: Transmission and evolution of a persistent pathogen: anthrax infection dynamics comparing two natural systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Anthrax is a globally distributed disease of wildlife, livestock, and humans.  Successful prediction of and response to outbreaks of anthrax is limited by a lack of understanding of the geographic differences in the ecology of the pathogen as well as the pattern of disease outbreaks.  This project will investigate the roles of host, pathogen, and environment to understand how the pathogen - host interaction evolves and contributes to the differences in anthrax occurrence between two study areas. The two areas, both in southern Africa, have very different anthrax outbreak dynamics, which are representative of variation in anthrax systems world-wide. In Etosha National Park, Namibia, there are smaller outbreaks, affecting grazing zebra, annually in wet seasons. In contrast, in Kruger National Park, South Africa, larger outbreaks affecting browsing kudu occur in dry seasons on roughly a decadal scale. The project builds on detailed records of disease and population dynamics in each park as well as archived pathogen samples and will involve new data collection and analyses and mathematical modeling to understand these different dynamics. Education, training, and scientific and public outreach are essential components of this research. Postdoctoral researchers and undergraduate and graduate students from diverse backgrounds will be trained in field, laboratory, and quantitative techniques emphasizing cutting-edge genomics, and statistical and dynamic modeling approaches. 

The causative agent of anthrax (the bacterium Bacillus anthracis), is often invoked as a textbook example for the evolution of high virulence and prolonged environmental survival. This project will link within-host, between-host, and in-environment processes, to understand how conflicting selective pressures impact pathogen diversity, host resistance, disease incidence, and ultimately, how these processes may drive host-pathogen co-evolution. This collaborative research team will compare anthrax dynamics in two wildlife systems, integrating long-term field studies, host and pathogen genomics, microbiology, and statistical and dynamic modeling. The project addresses three related questions: (1) how does pathogen diversity affect trade-offs between pathogen transmission and virulence? (2) how does host diversity affect trade-offs between pathogen transmission and virulence? and (3) how do landscape-scale patterns of transmission and host movement affect virulence-transmission trade-offs and host-pathogen population dynamics? Researchers will link variability in B. anthracis genomes to phenotype (i.e., pathogen survival in the environment, virulence to hosts, and transmission across host and geographic range). Researchers will identify host genes under pathogen-mediated selection in two primary host species, plains zebra (Equus quagga) and greater kudu (Tragelaphus strepsiceros). Researchers will build landscape-level models of epidemiology and population dynamics incorporating host movement, transmission routes, pathogen virulence, and host resistance.  Finally, researchers will build models predicting anthrax transmission dynamics across ecosystems. In a broader sense, this research will facilitate the development of predictive tools to better manage public health and related policies for complex, multi-host zoonotic diseases such as anthrax.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated the roles of host, pathogen and environmental variation in the risk of transmission and outbreak timing and intensity for a highly persistent bacterial pathogen capable of infecting a diversity of hosts with the lethal disease, anthrax. Bacillus anthracis is of considerable interest in its own right concerning public health, agriculture, and biosecurity and is a useful model organism for understanding other endemic and emerging diseases, as it combines high virulence with a variety of transmission modes, high environmental survival, and a wide host range. Using a unique set of data on naturally occurring anthrax in herbivorous mammals in Namibia and South Africa, our goal was to test, extend, and integrate theoretical understanding of pathogen evolutionary trade-offs, including virulence evolution and transmission strategies. 

Project accomplishments include a review of how environmental variation and pathogen survival alter virulence-transmission relationships. We evaluated how host ecological, behavioral and immunological traits interacted with local environmental conditions to alter the timing and intensity of anthrax outbreaks. We improved methods for detection of Bacillus anthracis from non-pathogenic close neighbors in genetic and serological studies. Extending beyond anthrax, we conducted a serological survey for dozens of other pathogens of concern in the region and note limitations of current diagnostic tests for characterizing the diversity of some of these disease agents in different ecosystems.

We calculated Bacillus anthracis spore survival rates in soils surveyed annually over a 12-year period and determined factors altering spore counts–or how infectious these soil reservoirs remain–over time. Combining spore survival data with host behaviors at carcass sites and simulation models, we determined how many secondary infections arise from an anthrax carcass site and how the environment alters the number of infections at a site, ranging from no infections to explosive outbreaks depending on when the animal died, weather conditions altering vegetation growth, and host foraging behavior at infectious sites. 

Using a combination of population genetics theory and the genetic diversity of Bacillus anthracis in terminal cases of anthrax in wildlife hosts, we estimated exposure doses and infection duration in wild populations. We described the global genomic diversity of Bacillus anthracis and identified candidate genes that may underlie functional differences in virulence or transmissibility among different lineages of this pathogen. We sequenced hundreds of genomes of Bacillus anthracis from across decades of outbreaks in two ecosystems, to characterize outbreak diversity patterns linked to different underlying epidemiological and evolutionary processes. 

Ongoing work continues to investigate pathogen survival under different soil types, host genomic signatures of susceptibility, pathogen evolution and diversity, and host community ecology, behavior and habitat selection in anthrax outbreak dynamics, and whether agent based models of disease developed in one ecosystem can be applied to understand disease dynamics in another. 

Our project has provided broader impacts to society by facilitating the training, research, and professional development of graduate students, postdoctoral researchers, undergraduate researchers, and research technicians; informing educational materials used to train undergraduates, graduate students, and professionals; and communicating results at conferences, meetings and public outreach venues. We fostered research collaborations and broadened research networks with microbiologists, geneticists, statisticians and qualitative ecologists, and wildlife biologists internationally. The project has informed methodologies for the detection and surveillance of an important pathogen of concern, and estimated key epidemiological parameters describing where, when and how anthrax infections occur in free-ranging wildlife.
